```{r}
setwd(here::here("data/"))
GermanCredit <- read_csv("GermanCreditClean.csv")
```

## Exploratory Data Analysis

```{r}
# GermanCredit accepted
YES_GC <- filter(GermanCredit,RESPONSE=="1")
```

```{r}
# GermanCredit refused
NO_GC <- filter(GermanCredit,RESPONSE=="0")
```

The dataset is related to the German Credit. Each applicant is described by 30 variables and the credit application is graded by good or bad.

Let's have a look at the distribution of the applications graded as good and bad

```{r, message=FALSE}
# Distribution of the grade of the applications
GermanCredit %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = RESPONSE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  scale_x_discrete(labels=c("0"="bad","1"="good")) +
  labs(title = "Number of credit applications per grade",
       y = "Number of applications",
       x = "Grade of applications")
```

```{r}
# Distribution of the numerical columns, i.e. duration, amount age

p.duration <- GermanCredit %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = DURATION, y = as.factor(RESPONSE))) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Duration of the credit applications",
       x = "Months",
       y = "Grade")

# Not a lot to say about the duration of the credits. It varies a lot.

p.amount <- GermanCredit %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = AMOUNT, y = as.factor(RESPONSE))) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Amount of the credit applications",
       x = "DM",
       y = "Grade")

# Small amount better chance

# Age

p.age <- GermanCredit %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = AGE, y = as.factor(RESPONSE))) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Age of the credit applicants",
       x = "Years",
       y = "Grade")



# It is skewed, the younger, the better 

p.amount
p.duration
p.age
```


```{r, include=FALSE}
# let's check if old people have basically more credit than young people
mean_yes<-mean(YES_GC$AGE)
mean_yes

mean_no<-mean(NO_GC$AGE)
mean_no

# age does not seem to be a key criterion 
```
